title: gamers-enjoy-e-sports-success-gala-fairydean-rovers
story: A TEAM of online gamers are representing Gala Fairydean Rovers FC in a virtual football competition.Gas engineer Darren Smith, of Galashiels, helped launch an -a-side league on FIFA  in which his hometown club has been enjoying considerable success.Smith, , told the Border : ldquoConsidering itrsquos the first season, itrsquos been excellent ndash and so has the reaction wersquove got from people.The Scottish league, played on a PlayStation , contains a number of teams representing official clubs, including Berwick Rangers, Greenock Morton andEast Stirlingshire.But the Galashiels side has been performing admirably, according to Smith ndash who has his sights set on a lofty finish.ldquoWersquove only beaten twice, said Smith, whose side currently sit third. ldquoLast Sunday we got beaten and we got beaten on the first day of the season.He added: ldquoWersquore still to play the second-placed team and wersquore still to play the team at the top.ldquoI thinkwe go unbeaten and they drop a few points, itrsquos there to be done and Irsquod be happy with second place.A total of  players have signed up to Galarsquos virtual squad, with three players from the town itself.As the recruitment drive was mainly carried out through Twitter, Smith was able to procure the services of gamers from across Britain and further afield. One of the goalkeepers, for instance, lives in Egypt.Asked to describe what it is like playing a video game in co-operation with  other people, Smith indicated it has been a hugely enjoyable experience.He said: ldquoPlaying with  others is sometimes challenging when it comes to getting everyone on for a certain time.ldquoHowever, being manager of the team, I have the luxury of picking who is in the team and I have managed to get some really good guys in who are competitive but also able to enjoy playing the game, which is what its all about in the end.When the real-le football season is in full swing, Smith takes to the park for Lauder Amateur FC.But, for now, the left-back is quite happy plying his trade for Gala online - and he is already considering adding a second tier to the virtual set-up next season.ldquoThe competition gives people a place to go and relax and enjoy themselves without the stresses of les problems, he said.

title: galashiels-postman-wears-superhero-costume-round
story: A GALASHIELS postman has been wearing a superhero costume while delivering parcels.James Morley, , of Melrose, raises a chuckle on his round by donning an Iron Man suit with his high-vis vest.Mr Morley said: "If people smile or laugh because of me, thats all I wanted."The stunt has been particularly popular with older residents, according to Mr Morley.He said: "Older people are at home and havent been able to see their grandchildren and families."A lot of them wanted the photos so they could say that Iron Man delivered their post."Ive had people whove missed me asking me to come back round again so they can get photos and their children can see me through the window."But Mr Morley, based at Galashiels Delivery Office, might not be the only superhero postie in town for much longer.He told the Border : "I may have convinced colleagues to join me. Were trying to organise a day when we can all dress up."Most of my colleagues, when I said I was going to do this, they didnt believe me until I walked into the office."It is unclear whether other members of the Marvel Avengers will join Mr Morley, but some residents are already suggesting he showcase other superheroes, including Spiderman and Batman.For now, however, Mr Morley and his colleagues ndash in costume or not ndash are continuing to provide their key service in abnormal circumstances."Our job has changed drastically," Mr Morley said. "In some respects its easier, leaving parcels at the door for contactless deliveries, but its a bit like Christmas as everyones at home so theyre ordering more as they cant go out."Its like Christmas but with fewer staff, too."Were just trying our best to press on with bringing parcels and letters to people."If you know of any other key workers going above and beyond to improve peoples days during lockdown, get in touch by emailing editorial@bordertelegraph or by messaging our Facebook page at www.facebook bordertelegraph

title: whirlpool-washing-machine-recall-extended-models---full-list
story: An additional  washing machines and tumble dryers haved been recalled by Whirlpool after being deemed to be a fire risk.Heres what you need to doyou have an affected model.What hasWhirlpool said The update comes from the Whirlpool website as ofApril , which states: ldquoAs part of ongoing in-depth checks carried out by Whirlpoolrsquos safety team, we are adding  additional models to the recall.The machines are being recalled because, as Whirlpool explains:ldquoWhen the heating element in the washing machine is activated, in very rare cases a component in the door lock system can overheat, which, depending on product features, can pose a risk of fire.If you have already checked your machine due to previous recalls, you will need to check it again.The recalled washing machines were manufactured under the brands of Hotpoint and Indesit between  and .The full list of recalled modelsThese are the recalled models that have been added to the list of recalled machines by Whirlpool:WMAQB P UKWMAQB P UKWMAQB G UKWMAQB P UKWMAQF P UK.LWMAQF G UKWMAQF P UKWMAQF P UKWMAQG G UKWMAQG P UKWMAQG P UKWMAQG P UK.MWMAQG P UK.MWMAQL P UKWMAQL P UKWMAQL A UKWMAQL P UKWMAQL P UK.MWMAQL G UKWMAQL P UKWMSAQG G UKHow to checkyoursquore affectedIf you think your washing machine is affected by the recall,head to the dedicated Whirlpool recall website-washingmachinerecall.whirlpool.Yoursquoll need to enter your postcode and your model number, and the website will be able to tell youyour model is part of the recall.If it is, yoursquoll then be taken to a new page which asks you to register, which will allow Whirlpool to get in contact with you.Yoursquoll need to fill out your name, email address, phone number and home address. Yoursquoll also need to state where you bought the machine from as well.Alternatively, you can phone   .What happensmy machine is being recalled If your machine is affected by the recall, then you are advised to unplug your appliance and stop using it immediately.If you must continue using it, you should use only a cold water cycle of  degrees celsius or lower.This will stop the washing machinersquos heating element from being activated and therefore poses less of a risk.Whirlpool Vice President, Jeff Noel, said:ldquoWe will still continue to provide a free-of-charge replacement of comparable specication or in-home engineering repair to all affected customers in as safe a way as possible.ldquoWe understand that in the current climate, some customers will have health and safety concerns around our delivery partners or engineers entering their homes to carry out replacements or repairs.ldquoWe continue to follow government guidelines, with strict health and safety processes across our operations, including equipping all our delivery drivers and engineers with personal protective equipment and hand sanitiser.ldquoHowever, we will also offer customers the option of contactless delivery and removal of affected appliances.

title: melrose-shops-praise-volunteers-free-deliveries-start
story: TRADERS in Melrose have joined forces to offer free delivery to customers who are unable to leave their homes.Butcher Martin Baird, , has recruited a raft of volunteer drivers to serve products from his shop and three others.Mr Baird said customer feedback has been ldquogreat, adding: ldquoWe had nearly  deliveries today ndash itrsquos really gone bananas.Other businesses taking part in the scheme are the Country Kitchen Deli, the Premier newsagent and vegetable shop Purple Plum.Mr Baird, whose shop has been on the high street for  years, said at least  people have volunteered to deliver.ldquoI try to give them payment, but they wonrsquot accept it ndash so I just give them a bit of meat, he told the Border .Drop-offs are being made in Galashiels almost every day, said Mr Baird, with some households in Stow, Bowden and Kelso also seeking help.Mr Baird said his business has always been popular, but demand has shot up during the coronavirus lockdown.He said: ldquoIrsquove taken on a couple of youngsters just for this period andthis keeps up, I might have to employ a couple more, because I canrsquot keep working  hours a week.Ready-made meals are proving to be a major hit, Mr Baird said. title: mays-super-flower-moon-see-uk
story: A so-called lsquoFlower Moonrsquo will be spotted over the skies of the UK this week.Not only that, but Mays full moon will also be a supermoon, making it a Super Flower Moon.But just what does all that mean What is a Flower Moon The May full moon is traditionally known as the Flower Moon simply because it appears at the time of blossoming flowers.What is a supermoon The moon - our planets only natural satellite - actually follows an elliptical orbit around the Earth.This means that at certain points on its egg-shaped path, it can be further away, or closer to us - a dferential of about , miles.The closest point is called the perigee, and the furthest is the apogee. When a full moon falls on the perigee, it appears far bigger and brighter in the sky and becomes known as a supermoon.The phenomenon is not actually that rare, and this months is last in a trilogy that began with Marchs full moon..During a supermoon,the diameter of the moon canappear to be about  per cent greater than an average full moon.What timewill the moon be biggest The full moon will be in the night sky on the evening of Thursday, May , though it will technically be at its fullest at :am on Thursday morning.Seeing as it wont even be in the sky then - let alone visible in daylight - the fullest youll get to see the moon will come at around .pm on Thurday, when the moon rises.It will be in the sky all night, and wont set again until about .am the following morning, offering plenty of time for you to catch a glimpse.For the best effect ndash and the closest yoursquoll get to witnessing the spectacular images seen across social media following such an event ndash yoursquoll want to look east shortly after moonrise.ldquoWhen the moon is near the horizon, it can look unnaturally large when viewed through trees, buildings, or other foreground objects," say NASA."The effect is an optical illusion, but that fact doesnrsquot take away from the experience."What  should I look out for This months full moon ties in nicely with the peak of the Eta Aquariids meteor shower.The meteor shower has been going on above our heads for a couple of weeks, and runs roughly from April  - May .However, it is this week when budding astronomers are likely to get the best show, as the shower peaks on the night of May  into May .The Eta Aquariids should be visible with the naked eye, although the glare from a full supermoon will make them harder to spot.Those living in built up areas would usually be advised to travel to less populated spaces and to avoid light pollutionthey really want to see the shower, but with ongoing lockdown restrictions and the coronavirus pandemic, that is not advised.Wrapping up in warm clothes is recommended, and you should allow up to  minutes for your eyes to fully adjust to the night sky.The Eta Aquariids are not one of the years most spectacular meteor showers, and usually peak at around  meteors per hours - thats just under one a minute.

title: caring-woman-guarding-door-borders-chemist
story: WHEN the Peebles Fat Face store closed its doors along with every other shop on the High Street, assistant manager Jane McGarry wasnrsquot home for long before going back to work.No sooner had she hung up the closed sign, Jane began a new voluntary post at a vital store directly opposite.She explained: ldquoWe closed on the Saturday before lockdown. I saw a post for help in Boots chemist on the COVID support page on the Monday morning and was in Boots an hour later.Janersquos new role involves manning the door of the chemist as people queue to pick up medicines.ldquoI roughly do five or six hours a day, Monday to Saturday," she said."My main role is basically to make sure I only let two people in the shop at a time.ldquoThe public are great and understanding. I also take repeat prescriptions so people donrsquot have to queue.Jane joked that she probably now knows the layout in Boots better than she does in Fat Face.ldquoIrsquom getting to know where things are in the shop so I can assist people," she said, adding: ldquoIt feels great to do my bit, evenit is just a cheery face or a friendly hello."While Jane helps people by handing in prescriptions, Peebles student Annie Patterson has proved a dab hand at delivering them.Annie is studying veterinary nursing at Edinburgh Napier University and was due to start her summer placement before the coronavirus outbreak.She said: ldquoAt the beginning of the pandemic, I saw that the NHS was recruiting volunteers throughout the UK."I asked Danielle at Bootsthey needed a hand delivering prescriptions. I wanted to use this time I now had available to help others.ldquoI have been doing this Monday to Saturday for six weeks now and itrsquos great because the majority of people are so grateful."

title: 65th-anniversary-couple-met-galashiels-academy
story: A COUPLE will celebrate their th anniversary today by speaking to family over Zoom.Charlie and Evelyn Renton, of St Boswells, were married on May , , at Melrose Parish Church.With coronavirus restrictions in place, a traditional family reunion is not possible ndash but the pair have been looking forward to a virtual get-together.Reflecting on their long marriage, Mrs Renton, , said: ldquoWersquove been very happy and healthy and very lucky.The couple, who first met at Galashiels Academy, moved from Mr Rentonrsquos native Galashiels to the Republic of Ireland in .Mrs Renton, originally from Melrose, had qualied as a nurse in Edinburgh, while Mr Renton, , enjoyed a career as a textile designer.The couple have three children , three grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.They ed to the Borders in , moving into their current home in St Boswells.

title: ve-day-75th-anniversary-2-coin-much-may-worth---get-one
story: To mark the th anniversary of VE Day -the Royal Mint has released a commemorative pound coin.Hereseverything you need to know about the new collection from the Royal Mint - including how to get your hands on a coin and how much it costs.Why has the Royal Mint made a commemorative coin The Royal Mint website says: ldquoSeventy-fiveyears on [from VE Day], we thank the generation who gave so much and honour their spirit and sacrice.VE Day stands for Victory in Europe Day, and it refers to May , , when Germany surrendered their armed forces during World War II.The coin from the Royal Mint aims to ldquoremember the first hopeful steps towards lasting peace and the promise of a brighter future.The isional director of commemorative coins at the Royal Mint, Clare Maclennan, said that she hoped the VE Day coins would bring Britain together during the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.Maclennan said: ldquoOur VE Day commemorative coin was inspired by a shared sense of community and loyalty.ldquoDuring these challenging times that the nation finds itself in, we may be unable to join with our loved ones to mark this national milestone, but it feels especially important that we come together to protect the older generation that sacriced so much for us.What coins are available to buy If you want to get your hands on the commemorative pound coin from the Royal Mint, you have a few options.The th anniversary of VE Day pound uncirculated coin comes in educational packaging all about VE Day and Winston Churchill. This costs pound.There is also the th anniversary of VE Day silver proof pound coin. This coin is limited edition, with only , made. It costs pound..Next is the th anniversary of VE Day piedfort silver pound coin. Also limited edition, only , have been made. This coin costs pound.Last is the th anniversary of VE Day gold proof pound coin. This is also an extremely limited edition coin, as only  were made. This coin costs pound,.Alternatively, you can purchase a th anniversary of VE Day gold proof pound coin with a period newspaper, which allows you to read the news of VE Day as it was reported from an original period newspaper.This is an extremely limited edition package with only  available to buy. It costs pound, and because itrsquos so rare, yoursquoll need to phone The Royal Mint on    to place an order.For each coin purchased, a donation will be made to the Imperial War Museums.What do the coins look like The coins feature a design which shows the celebrating public with the word lsquovictoryrsquo across the top.Designer Dominique Evans said: ldquoIconic images of VE Day serve to remind us of the magnitude of events.ldquoMillions came together in the streets to celebrate the end of the war in Europe, inspiring me to put the people at the very heart of this coin. The rays evoke search lights, a familiar sight in the skies during wartime, except here they represent rays of home.

title: historic-borders-house-needs-20k-planned-re-opening
story: A STATELY home in the Borders needs pound, so it can re-open to the public in the summer, according to trustees.Paxton House, in Berwickshire, has been closed since the beginning of the coronavirus lockdown in March.But now the Paxton Trust is urging the public to donate by June  so the th century estate can open its doors again in July.Trust chairman Ian Marrian said: ldquoWe want to re-open as soon as itrsquos safe for all and wersquoll have to invest to ensure that safety."We cannot compromise on the conservation of our nationally signicant collections and the glorious natural landscape."But every day without income makes survival a greater challenge."Mr Marrian said the trust is also working "extremely hard" to try to gain a grant to cover the essential running costs for .He added: "We hope that,and when we re-open, we can with your help and attendance make these strange times a little happier.The trust, which has earmarked July  for re-opening, says it needs pound, by the start of the summer to maintain the property, as well as the childrenrsquos playground and gardens.The house was gted to the nation in  by John David Home Robertson, the last laird, for the populations "benefit and enjoyment".Its collection of paintings includes work by Allan Ramsay, Sir Henry Raeburn and Alexander Nasmyth.The house also boasts Scotlands largest collection of Thomas Chippendale furniture.

title: selkirk-firms-help-make-25-000-face-shields
story: TWO Selkirk companies have combined to help make more than , face shields for hospitals and local businesses.Cademuir Engineering and Eadie Bros and Co have worked together since the start of April to supply D-printed visors, of which , have been sent to Selkirk-based workwear distributor Guthrie Group.The Guthrie Groups Selkirk manager Alan Skeldon said: ldquoIts great to have local businesses with the ability to make face shields, allowing us to supply to local healthcare facilities.A club of engineering enthusiasts based in Edinburgh, called Edinburgh Shield Force, contacted Eadie Bros for help making personal protective equipmentfor frontline workers.The engineers needed headbands for the face shields they were distributing to Scottish healthcare workers, including those at the Borders General Hospital.Using Eadie Brosrsquo injection-moulding tool, Cademuir made the headbands using state-of-the art equipment which enables each part to be robotically handled, minimising contamination risk and increasing the production rate to , a day.Cademuir Engineering production manager Marc Phaup said: ldquoIts fantastic to be involved in this important project for our NHS, along with supplying local businesses like Guthrie Group.ldquoThere are a lot of dferent groups who have come together to achieve the goal of getting PPE to our frontline workers.A spokesperson for the Edinburgh Shield Force added: ldquoThis project has only been possible because of the combined experience of our team, the tireless dedication of our volunteers and the flexibility and hard work of our partners Eadie Bros and Co and Cademuir Engineering.Edinburgh Shield Force is relying on a fundraising appeal, which you can access through this link.

title: man-shows-off-160-year-old-copy-borders-newspaper
story: A BORDERS man has come forward with a -year-old copy of a local newspaper.Mitchell Johnston, of Peebles, spotted last weekrsquos articlein the Peeblesshire Newsdocumenting council leader Shona Haslamrsquos surprise discovery while renovating her new house.Mrs Haslam unearthed an edition of the Peebles Newsdated February , , when tidying up the old courthouse at Peebles High Street.But now Mr Johnston, , wishes to showcase one of his own prized possessions ndash a copy of the Peeblesshire Advertiserfrom December , .Mr Johnston, a retired member of the merchant navy, said the paper had originally belonged to his uncle John Somerville, who emigrated to Canada in about  and became the manager of a mill.Mr Johnston said Somerville, born in , died in . title: 100th-staging-agricultural-show-postponed
story: FARMERS will have to wait until next year for the th staging of a Borders agricultural show.Organisers of Yarrow  Ettrick Pastoral Society Show have taken the decision to cancel the  edition.The societys secretary Alison Renwick said the committee "felt duty-bound" to call off the showpiece.She added: ldquoThis yearrsquos show would have been particularly memorable, as committee members had already started working on a number of special projects to commemorate the th staging.ldquoThese plans will, of course, now be carried over to the  event and Irsquom very confident next yearrsquos show will prove every bit as successful as this yearrsquos would have been.Although the first show staged by the Yarrow  Ettrick Pastoral Society took place in September, , the societyrsquos origins stretch back  years prior to that with the formation of the Selkirk Farmer Club .The new societyrsquos formation came after a public meeting was held in the Gordon Arms in May, , to "consider the desirability of forming a society for the purpose of organising an annual show of sheep and cattle".Descendants of farmers present at that inaugural meeting continue to live and work in the Yarrow and Ettrick Valleys, thereby helping to keep alive the traditions and high standards which have become the hallmark of the societyrsquos past  shows.The organisers added: "We would like to take this opportunity to thank everyone involved with Yarrow Show, including all volunteers, sponsors, traders, exhibitors and public, whose support is essential to the future of the show."The society looks forward to welcoming you back next year."

title: borders-college-students-deliver-medicine-vulnerable-folk
story: BORDERS College students are delivering medicine to vulnerable peoplersquos homes during lockdown.A total of  students and staff have given up their time to drop off more than  prescriptions across the region.The colleges work placement co-ordinator Verity Hislop said: "The students are quite happy to do it ndash they enjoy it."The college is working with NHS Borders and Scottish Borders Council to run the scheme, which is being led by Ms Hislop.She said: ldquoAlthough wersquove no direct contact with the iniduals wersquore delivering to, we get a wave or a smile or a thank you from a distance."And we certainly know they are appreciative, from the expression on their face."If we didnrsquot deliver, they wouldnrsquot be able to get their medicines.ldquoThese are iniduals who fall into the vulnerable group ndash theyrsquove been told by the NHS they need to isolate.ldquoThere was a huge demand on pharmacies and a lot of iniduals in ious communities fall into the vulnerable category."We sent out a call to staff and students ndash but only those who are PVGscheme members."All the Borders staff fall under that, and also the health and social care students."Originally, pharmacies notied the NHS Borders Transport Hub about prescriptions that needed to be picked up.But now pharmacies are contacting the Borders College delivery team directly with their requests.ldquoThe Transport Hub emailed me with requests for prescription pick-ups from the pharmacy, said Ms Hislop, ldquoand then I would arrange for volunteers to go to the pharmacies, pick up the prescription and deliver them to the people who needed them.ldquoBut now wersquore getting phone calls directly from the pharmacies, with the increase in demand.She added: ldquoBorders College sees its role as supporting our community and during these unprecedented times there is a desire to contribute and add value by volunteering.ldquoThe college is exceptionally proud and grateful to everyone who is involved. This collaborative mission helps to protect vulnerable groups within the community and potentially saves lives.ldquoA huge thank you to all the volunteers, NHS Borders and NHS Transport Hub.

story: GALASHIELS rugby players have raised more than pound, for the local foodbank ndash and delivered carloads of supplies.Over two successive weekends, Gala RFC invited supporters to drop off food at the gates of Scott Park.Gala president Ian Dalgleish said: ldquoEveryonersquos generosity was fantastic.The weekend of April - saw nearly pound left by players, committee members, supporters and the general public ndash in addition to bags of groceries.The second weekend of collections, on May , raised pound ndash including a bottle of coins totalling pound from residents at Abbotsford Court.Mr Dalgleish said: ldquo[Captain] Euan Dods and [vice captain] Rex Jeffrey and other volunteers were collecting the food and donations at Scott Park, and then the bags were delivered to St Peterrsquos Church for the foodbank.ldquoThe bottle of coins donated by the folk at Abbotsford Court was pound ndash they donrsquot have a lot of money to give out but when they found out there was pound in the bottle they actually topped it up to pound.Galashiels Foodbank co-ordinator John Tucker said: ldquoWe are really thrilled to have all this local support.ldquoNearly pound, was raised in two weekends, and Herculean amounts of food ndash two carloads of food both weekends ndash so our stocks are right up to where we want them to be, which is wonderful.ldquoIn times of hardship people are thinking of each other. The public have really got their support behind this initiative and they just came along with food and money.ldquoBefore COVID, we were giving out maybe  carrier bags of food a week."At [the viruss peak] about two weeks ago we gave out  ndash a fourfold increase in demand.And the foodbank is not the only local charity to benefit from the generosity of the rugby club players.Gala Menrsquos Shed, whose members are making face visors for care workers, was the grateful recipient of a pound donation by the rugby club.Scottish Borders Menrsquos Shed developer Ross Hall described the donation as "fantastic".He said: "It took us over a wee setback in terms of supply, and Gala stepped in at just the right time to help us make more visors."So we had a wee break due to funding and now wersquore back on track. title: aussie-rugby-player-caring-galashiels-lockdown
story: A KIND-HEARTED Australian rugby player has been delivering food to elderly folk in the Borders town he currently calls home.Gala RFC forward Cody Roman, , moved from Wollongong, New South Wales, in October last year.When coronavirus put paid to his plans to explore more of the Borders, he decided to channel his free time into volunteering as a driver with Food Train.He said: ldquoIrsquom fortunate that Irsquom mobile so I want to get out and help those who are less fortunate or in need."For six weeks, Cody has been dropping off food to residents who are self-isolating.He said: ldquoIt got to the end of winter and I was looking forward to seeing some nice summer days, and then this [lockdown] happened.ldquoThe club put a post on social media askingthere were any guys ready to help out with anything, like shopping or dog-walking or anything that people were unable to do now, for people who had to self-isolate.ldquoThe Food Train commented on the post, and I was like, lsquoIrsquoll do itrsquo. And Irsquove being doing it for six weeks now.ldquoItrsquos been really good ndash everyone appreciates it. Some people who live alone might not have seen anyone for a few days, so theyrsquore very happy when we come out to them and have a chat.ldquoSome of them are very excited and grateful. Some of them offer us a cup of tea and we have to let them down easy."Despite being so far from his home Down Under, Cody is coping well with the coronavirus lockdown.ldquoItrsquos not too bad, with Facebook and social media and stuff. I can just send messages and give people a call."And Irsquom pretty fortunate where I live ndash everyonersquos very friendly.

title: ex-lauder-footballer-toasts-50th-anniversary-cup-win
story: A REUNION to mark the th anniversary of Lauder Amateur FC clinching the South of Scotland Cup has been cancelled due to coronavirus.Lauder triumphed - over Tweeddale Rovers at Netherdale, Galashiels, on May , .Members of the successful side had been planning to meet up this summer, but COVID- has put paid to the proposal.George Threadgall, , told the Border that he still treasures memories of Lauderrsquos achievement.ldquoIt was like the European Cup for us, said the former defender, adding: ldquoI think half of Lauder was there that night.Led by coaches Jim Brotherston and Alex McDonald, Lauder went down - through an own goal, recalled Mr Threadgall, before roaring back to put their noses in front.After Rovers hoofed a penalty kick over the bar in the dying minutes, Mr Threadgall and team-mates celebrated a famous victory when they arrived home.ldquoYou go to Lauder and mention the South team and locals will bore you to tears about how big a thing it was for the town, said Mr Threadgall, a retired engineer living in Linlithgow.Lauderrsquos goals came courtesy of forwards Jimmy Gillie and Stan Seaton, said Mr Threadgall, with centre-half Kenny Rutherford being the unfortunate player who turned the ball into his own net.The reunion had been planned for late July or early August in Lauderrsquos Golden Bannock pub, said Mr Threadgall.Guests would have included Dave Elrick, now living in South Africa, who was Lauder Cornet in the year he helped his hometown side to the cup.Mr Threadgall, a grandfather, was himself Lauder Cornet in .

title: northern-ireland-unveils-five-point-plan-exiting-coronavirus-lockdown
story: Groups of four to six people who do not share a household will be allowed to meet outdoors while maintaining social distancing in one of the first steps in Northern Irelandrsquos road map out of lockdown.A five-point plan with no firm dates has been published for exiting coronavirus restrictions.Those unable to work from home will be encouraged toto work on a phased basis in another early shtthe reproductive rate at which the virus is spread continues to decline below one.Large outdoor-based retailers such as garden centres will also be permitted to reopen in the first step as le edges its way back towards normality.Executive publishes Coronavirus recovery strategy ##https:t.co egDPHjECmdash NI ExecutiveMay , The decision on when to make changes will be guided primarily by the medical and scientic evidence and the NHSrsquos capacity to cope.There is flexibility for dferent parts of the economy such asto schooling and increased use of public transport to move at dferent paces.Drive-through church services will be available and churches will open for private prayer at an early stage.Outdoor spaces and public sport amenities will also be included in the first step of reopening.Large indoor gatherings, nightclubs, concerts, close physical contact sports, restaurants, cafes, pubs and early years education will be included in the final, step five, relaxation.Stormontrsquos next regular three-weekly review of the restrictions is due at the end of May but will be guided by the medical evidence at the time.According to the blueprint, the second step will see groups of  being able to meet outdoors, team sports training allowed on a non-contact basis in small groups, the reopening of some libraries and open-air museums, as well as indoor activities involving limited contact of less than  minutes and with two to four people.The third step will see groups of up to  being able to gather outside, the reopening of more libraries, as well as museums and galleries, concert and theatre rehearsals resuming and larger indoor gatherings.The fourth step will see socially distanced church services, the resumption of competitive sport behind closed doors or with a limited number of spectators, leisure centres reopening and outdoor concerts resuming on a restricted basis.Stormont First Minister Arlene Foster told the Northern Ireland Assembly: ldquoOur road map wonrsquot answer every query ndash it provides an indication, which people can use in looking ahead and anticipating how the next weeks and months might evolve.The Stormont Executive said that, as of May , , iniduals in the region had been tested for Covid-, with , laboratory-confirmed cases and  reported deaths, adding that although overall case numbers are continuing to rise, it is at a slower rate than before.It also notes a ldquogradual decline in both hospital admissions and intensive care unit occupancy, reflecting a reduction in transmission of the virus and progression of the epidemic.The First Minister added: ldquoOur restrictions have worked and they have and are saving lives.ldquoWe are asking a lot of our people, and we appreciate that the restrictions have health and well being consequences too.ldquoWe want everyone to be able to go out, visit relatives, socialise and enjoy everything this place has to offer. We need to get people back to work where safe to do so. We will get there. It will take time, but we will get there.Northern Irelandrsquos R measure of virus transmission is at approximately level . and medics have said they want to drive it down further.The regulations will continue to be reviewed within every three-week period. There may be reviews where no change is warranted and others when more change is possible.Each process of review should not be read as being linked to the next step of the relaxations, Stormontrsquos road map said.Deputy First Minister Michelle OrsquoNeill told the Assembly: ldquoWe are appealing to the public to please be patient.ldquoThe restrictions remain in place at this time, because it is necessary and because it is thankfully working.ldquoOur biggest threat in the fight against Covid- is complacency.ldquoUntil a vaccine is found it means co-existing with the virus and therefore a radical change to how we live our daily lives for some time.ldquoLe as we know it has changed, we will have to continue to adjust..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Northern Ireland unveils five-point plan for exiting coronavirus lockdown

title: sisters-transform-bar-musselburghs-friendliest-pub
story: Rebecca and Victoria Fowler took over The Sportsman Bar in May last year, with a view to transforming the High Street premises.The venue has signed up to Best Bar None Scotland and Rebecca, of Tranent, felt it had made a massive dference in turning the business around.She said: ldquoHaving previously worked in The Sportsman, we knew what we were taking on but also knew it was something we could make work.ldquoThe pub had a bit of a reputation. We wanted to turn it into a safe place for people to come and enjoy a night out with a bit of banter thrown in: lsquoMusselburghrsquos friendliest pub.rsquo But we knew this wouldnrsquot happen overnight.Best Bar None Scotland aims to ensure everyone can enjoy a safe night out.The national scheme, which works through a partnership between local authorities, the Scottish Government, Police Scotland, Scottish Fire and Rescue Service and other organisations, works to reduce crime, reward excellence, and raise standards of alcohol licensed premises.Rebecca added: ldquoLicensing recommended we joined lsquoBest Bar Nonersquo and we were interested straight away since we knew we needed help to make the pub work.ldquoAfter speaking to the local co-ordinator and reading through the guidelines, we decided to use the lsquoBest Bar Nonersquo checklist as a guide to show us the safety changes we had to makethe pub was going to be a success.Rebecca and Victoria, of Wallyford, had both previously worked in the pub, which is at the junction of High Street and Newbigging.Rebecca told the Courier that promoting initiatives such as Ask Angela, designed to keep people safe from sexual assault by using a codeword to identy when they are in danger or an uncomfortable situation, had helped them achieve a silver Best Bar None award.She added: ldquoWe have now eliminated all the trouble and actively promote initiatives like lsquoAsk Angelarsquo.ldquoWe even hand out lollipops at the end of busy nights to help reduce noise.ldquoWe know that when our patrons leave the pub they are still our responsibility and need to get home safely.ldquoAll our customers now know that we operate a zerotolerance policy on trouble, including drugs.ldquoSafety has to be the top priority for any pub and, by working side by side with lsquoBest Bar Nonersquo, we know we are doing all that we can to create a friendly atmosphere for everyone who comes through the door, giving them an enjoyable and a safe night out.

title: extension-planned-school-prestonpans
story: East Lothian Council wants to add two classrooms to the east side of St Gabrielrsquos RC Primary School, in Prestonpans, as more housing being built in the town is expected to increase the Prestonpans.ldquoThe proposed work includes alterations to the nursery, increasing its space by expanding into the existing primary one classroom.ldquoAn extension will create space for a new primary one classroom and provide an additional classroom.ldquoOur five-year capital programme has allocated pound.m for the works, which are required to accommodate an increase in nursery provision through title: bridges-project-continues-vital-work-lockdown
story: Regular face-to-face sessions and group activities at the Bridges Project on Bogpark Road have been replaced with phone calls, text messages, video calls and digital work as the lockdown becomes challenging for some.Despite the dficult times as a result of the pandemic, staff have discovered ldquopositive elements of lsquoremotersquo working with young people in East Lothian and Midlothian. They have now been working from home for more than a month and have continued to support vulnerable and disadvantaged young people with ious issues which has brought about some ldquounexpected outcomes.Lynne Anderson, transitions development worker, has noticed that she is able to use her time more wisely by phoning her clients instead of driving up to an hour each way to visit them at their homes.She said: ldquoWe can use this situation to learn how things work dferently. There are opportunities to continue doing some of the activities we are doing remotely when weto normal.She is one of several staff members who have had to change the way they give support over the past weeks but it still focuses on many of the same issues. They provide help with filling out job and college applications, and provide young people with emotional support and tutoring. The response has also generally been very positive, with staff members reporting engagement levels of up to  per cent from their clients.Natasha McInninie, transitions service co-ordinator, said: ldquoI am surprised by how resilient young people are. I thought we would lose a lot of young people through this situation. However, it has actually made them engage more.Emma Scarclfe, acting chief executive, is also very pleased by how both Bridges Project staff and the young people they work with have responded to the current crisis.She said: ldquoBridges Project has adapted quickly to the unexpected situation around Covid-. Engagement continues to be extremely high and the commitment and dedication from staff to change their working practices so quickly to suit each inidual young person has been a complete triumph. Wersquore all very proud of the way young people have adapted and how resilient they are.However, there are also issues which have become ldquomagnied during the lockdown, for example, people who have dficult relationships with their family members struggle with being ldquolocked up together over such a long period. Others are affected by less income and need help with accessing food parcels, Universal Credit and other types of financial support.Many young people also need help to deal with the impact the Covid- crisis is having on their mental health. This is particularly the case for those who were already struggling with social anxiety or social isolation prior to the lockdown.Lynne said: ldquoIn the beginning, the young people thought it was fantastic. Now the reality of the lockdown is settling in and it is starting to become challenging.This trend has also been observed by personal development worker, Chris Nicol, who said: ldquoThe young people were dealing with it well during the first few weeks but have seen a downturn in their mood over the last two weeks. This is due to a combination of boredom and too much time to think but also not seeing their friends. They have realised how important those social anchors really are.He highlighted the importance of keeping young peoplersquos motivation and confidence up during these challenging times.He explained: ldquoI remind them that they need to focus on the fact that this will last for a relatively short period of their lives and things will go back to normal.Thank you for reading this story. title: lockdown-birthday-proves-one-remember-neighbours-wave
story: Ian Millar has been recovering from heart bypass surgery at his home in Haddington and, under lockdown guidelines, has been staying in.However, daughter Susan was determined to make sure his landmark birthday did not go unmarked, and decorated his car with balloons and a poster asking passers-by to wave to her dad.And, last Friday, lots of families out for their daily walk stopped to do just that.Susan said: ldquoDad has not been able to get out of the house and is recovering from his operation so I wanted to surprise him. title: thirty-seven-new-homes-given-green-light-dunbar
story: Thirty-seven new homes on the outskirts of Dunbar were given the go ahead, despite concerns lodged by the community council.The statutory consultee contacted East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department when Harrison Hunt Ltd and Hallhill Developments Ltdrsquos plans were submitted in November last year.The scheme, which was approved at the beginning of the month, is a mix of three and four-bedroom homes on the south-west corner of the Hallhill area.Community councillors outlined  concerns with the proposals, including the layout and footpath provision, as well as the effects on habitat and the increased demand on education provision in the town.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the group, said it could be ldquoincredibly depressing to feel the views of the community council were not being given full consideration.She said: ldquoAll the comments we continue to make about connectivity, safe routes to school, play spaces, maximising potential for ecological building... all of that and we just feel asit is ignored.ldquoIt will not stop us making the comments but it does sometimes feel aswe are whistling in the wind.The development, to the west of Yosemite Park and Fall Avenue, will consist of: four three-bedroom terraced homes  three-bedroom detached and semi-detached properties  four-bedroom detached homes and four four-bedroom semi-detached houses.The proposals were approved by the local authorityrsquos planning department, which said the homes would be ldquoappropriate to their location given their height, size and scale.The planning officer added: ldquoThe proposed residential development would provide an attractive residential environment. The residential units are shown to be laid out in such a way that adheres to the normally accepted privacy and amenity criteria on overlooking and overshadowing, whilst affording the future occupants of the residential units an appropriate level of privacy and residential amenity.Access to the new development would come from Fall Avenue and James Kirk Way.A design and access statement included within the planning application notes meetings had taken place with ious local authority departments in a bid to address ious design requirements.It concludes: ldquoOverall, it is considered that the final design creates a well-considered, proportionate design that responds to the site constraints and the nearby area to create a positive design solution.ldquoThe result is a development that will make a positive contribution socially, economically and aesthetically to the area and enhance the amenity of existing and future residents within this area.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council stressed they ldquowelcomed comments from community councils.She said: ldquoIn this case, we consulted the community council back in December, and they submitted a response detailing a number of concerns.ldquoThese included concerns over house type and layout, increased vehicle movement and parking space provision.ldquoWhilst we understand that consultees may be frustrated when planning authorities do not always agree with their comments, we must balance these comments against the other material considerations of each case.ldquoIn the case of the Hallhill application, our conclusion was that, subject to the imposition of conditions, the proposed development was acceptable.Thank you for reading this story. title: grey-squirrels-targeting-dirleton-bowling-clubs-clubhouse
story: Dirleton Bowling Club, which dates back almost  years, is aiming to refurbish its clubhouse because of the troublesome creatures.A new roof would be included in the works, which are being weighed up by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department.Improvements to the footpath would also be included but a design and access statement in the planning application highlights that it is squirrels which are the problem.It reads: ldquoThe catalyst for this improvement project is the extensive ongoing damage to the existing clubhouse roof caused by grey squirrels nesting in the roof during the past three winters.ldquoThey penetrate between the pantiles and nest underneath them, gnawing their way through to the clubroom itself.The bowling club has been part of the social fabric of the village for  years, with the clubhouse and steps to the bowling green built in .The design and access statement also spells out what the bowling club means to the village and the potential consequencesthe proposals are not given the go ahead.ldquoIt is the only village sports club providing exercise and social, intergenerational contact through sport, and the only village team representing the Dirleton community, reads the nine-page document.ldquoIf the practical issues set out below mean that the clubhouse becomes unusable, then the club will be unable to compete in the bowling leagues.ldquoThe expectation of visiting teams is now much higher than it used to be, and clubs such as North Berwick, Aberlady, Stenton and Gullane all have new improved facilities.ldquoThe clubhouse is dark and damp and the roof sarking boards are being damaged and holed by grey squirrels.ldquoThere is no lighting to the path, which is also muddy and slippery because water pours onto it from the adjacent derelict hall owned by the council.Now, the bowling club, which has about  members, is keen to see improvements carried out, with funding being sought to cover the cost of the scheme which has still to be calculated.A new metal roof could be put in place, with consideration being given to it blending in to the historic surroundings adjacent to Dirleton Castle.Two windows are proposed for the south side of the building to improve the lighting in the clubhouse, while three semi-mature trees could be removed. title: free-listings-site-promotes-independent-business
story: Tom Harries has come up with a free listings site ndash Edinburgh Lockdown Economy ndash which features  local businesses and their lockdown offers.Since its recent launch, the website has attracted around , visitors.It features everything from childrenrsquos activity packs and online fitness classes to craft ale orders from local breweries.Tom and his team behind the project hope that visitors will discover something on their doorstep they didnrsquot know existed, providing businesses with much-needed revenues that could help them survive until the restrictions are lted.ldquoMy we is a doctor at the Western General Hospital and I could see that local businesses were offering food and other support to help front line staff cope, said Tom, a user experiencedesign consultant who has worked with companies including yell, Virgin Media Business and Lloyds Banking Group.He added: ldquoI realised that many local businesses were at risk and could do with some support, too, so I built the site as a one-stop shop to show the public who was still in operation and what they could buy or access.ldquoSince we launched, the response from the community has been phenomenal.ldquoThe iety of services still on offer was a shock to me so Irsquod encourage anyone to take a look and feel inspired. It is easy to feel a bit down whilst wersquore stuck inside so I hope people find something here that cheers them up as well as supporting local businesses.There is no fee to be listed business owners can get in touch via edinburghlockdowneconomy add-somethingThe Edinburgh Lockdown Economy initiative is supported by Vocal, which helps customers share feedback directly to business managers and is part of the Royal Bank of Scotland Entrepreneur Accelerator programme.Thank you for reading this story. title: queens-maundy-money-sent-church-elders-post
story: Alan Miller and Margaret Jeffrey had been due to travel to St Georgersquos Chapel, Windsor, to attend the Royal Maundy Thursday Service.The annual ceremony sees Queen Elizabeth II present symbolic money to people who have supported their church and community but the event was sadly cancelled due to the global pandemic.Instead, Alan and Margaret, who were both delighted to be given the honour, received the purses in the post.Both of the recipients, who live in East Linton, were shocked to receive letters last year inviting them to the event.Alan told the Courier he was overwhelmed when the letter came in the post and said: ldquoThe first thing I thought was lsquois this a scam rsquoldquoThe outside of the envelope said it was from Buckingham Palace and when you opened the letter it said Her Majesty invites you to be the recipient of the Maundy money.ldquoIt just seemed so wild and asit was not true but then Margaret got the same letter and I realised that it was right.ldquoIt just blew my head away.ldquoIrsquove seen the Queen handing out the Maundy money down the years and I never in my wildest dreams imagined that I would get it.Seventy-five-year-old Alan, an elder at the Parish of Traprain for more than  years, was due to travel to the service, which was to take place on April , with his we, Eleanor.At the service, each recipient would be given two purses, one red ndash containing a pound coinand a p piece representing the GB Olympic Team ndash and one white .Due to the coronavirus and travelling and gathering restrictions, both Alan and Margaret received their purses in the post.Margaret, originally an elder at Whittingehame Parish Church before it became part of the Parish of Traprain in , had planned to make the trip south with her daughter, Susan.The former housekeeper at Abbeyfield House in East Linton was ldquodisappointed not to be able to attend the event at Windsor but stressed these were exceptional circumstances.She said: ldquoIrsquom fortunate I was even thought about to go.ldquoI think we have got to get things right in le ndash the world is in a grave situation at the minute.Modest Margaret, , told the Courier she had seen people down the years receiving the award but added: ldquoIrsquove just lived an ordinary le ndash Irsquove not done anything special.Thank you for reading this story. title: resilient-musselburgh-team-moves-due-increased-demand
story: The Resilient Musselburgh team was operating out of Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School but had to switch its hub to the Musselburgh East Community Learning Centre for more space to meet its growing needs.The initiative involvesMusselburgh  Inveresk Community Council, Musselburgh Area Partnership, Wallyford Community Council, Whitecraig Community Council and East Lothian Councilrsquos Connected Communities which are covering Musselburgh, Wallyford, Whitecraig and Old Craighall.Stuart Baxter, Connected Communities manager, said: ldquoThe Connected Communities Base, co-ordinating the supply of food and services directed by Resilient Musselburgh, has moved to the Musselburgh East Community Learning Centre .ldquoThe demand associated with the current Covid- crisis meant that the space available at Pinkie was insufficient and the move to MECLC allows greater space for storing necessary food and supplies, greater access to needed IT services and further space to allow additional staff to assist in the provision of these vital services to the most vulnerable in the community.He is working alongside community development officers Jane Cummings and Pamela Martin, and family support outreach worker Donna Doherty.They are supported by Musselburgh  Inveresk community councillors Irene Tait, Margaret Stewart and Bernard Harkins.Links to Wallyford and Whitecraig are maintained through regular contact with the chairpersons of their community councils, Alister Hadden and Shona Bennett.Mrs Stewart said: ldquoWe are currently working with a number of local businesses and organisations to provide the stock for emergency supplies including Tesco Musselburgh and the Pinkie Farm Shop.Thank you for reading this story. title: yummikeys-aiming-spread-joy-sunflower-seeds
story: Elspeth Fawcett set up Yummikeys three years ago, an eco-friendly toy company that makes stainless steel sensory toys for babies.Elspeth has started adding sunflower seeds to all of her orders for people to plant inside or in their gardens.The -year-old mum of three is also donating five per cent of all profits directly to For the Love of Scrubs, an initiative set up to provide scrubs to frontline NHS staff during the coronavirus pandemic, and Womenrsquos Aid.Elspeth said: ldquoI really want to do something to help spread happiness and joy over the coming weeks as I appreciate that this is such a dficult time for everyone.ldquoIrsquove chosen to add sunflower seeds to all orders as this is something that everyone can enjoy, even those who are not fortunate enough to have gardens. I love seeing all of the rainbows in peoples windows but we can only enjoy these for the short time that we are out exercising each day, so my intention is for these sunflowers to be enjoyed for the rest of the time we are at home or in our gardens.On donating her profits she added: ldquoIrsquom a small business working hard to overcome the challenges that coronavirus has placed on all of our lives, but I feel this is really the right thing to do as my donation will hopefully help those who need it most right now.Thank you for reading this story. title: community-resilience-can-turn-help
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at five of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Cockenzie and Port SetonTHE resilience effort in Cockenzie and Port Seton has been helping launch a Fair Share hub at the Port Seton Centre this past week.The charity Fair Share delivers surplus food from supermarkets to the centre every Friday.The hub will cover the whole of East Lothian and support the centrersquos existing work to provide hot meals and food packs to families in need and children who would usually receive free school meals.Bryan Hickman, chairman of the local community council, which is leading the resilience effort, said: ldquoWe are still delivering food to those who need it but the Fair Share hub has been set up.ldquoWe receive food like coffee, cereal, milk and biscuits but this could change every week.ldquoItrsquos really good news that we have set this up as it will help us give other types of food. It will also help us financially because it is free.Meanwhile, the resilience effort is continuing to help those in need when requests come in, and currently has about  volunteers.A volunteer has also started offering a dog walking service.Contact detailsThose who require assistance can call the resilience emergency number on  . Updates are also posted on the Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council Twitter twitter CandPSCC and Facebook pages www.facebook Cockenzie-and-Port-Seton-Community-Council-.East SaltounHumbie, East and West Saltoun and BoltonFOUR volunteer groups are operating to help residents of neighbouring rural villages during the coronavirus pandemic.A resilience group, involving members of the Humbie, East and West Saltoun and Bolton Community Council, was previously formed.Alastair Beck, community council treasurer, said: ldquoVolunteers in the four village groups are supporting residents in their communities.ldquoAnyone in need of support, whether for shopping, pharmacy runs, etc, or who would just like someone to talk to should make contact with their village coordinator.Contact detailsPeople in Bolton should contact Shena Jamieson on   or by email shenajamieson@aol.East Saltoun residents can contact Buffy Neilson on   or buffyneilson@yahoo.In West Saltoun, Derek Smith is the point of contact on   or by emailing coruisk@gmail.Finally, in Humbie, people are encouraged to call Margo Hodge on   or email humbiehelp@gmailMacmerryMacmerry and GladsmuirA LEAFLET drop to all residents across Macmerry and Gladsmuir last week led to the numbers of calls dealt with by the resilience team double.The team also offer a hot food service, and requests for this have quadrupled in the past week from two to eight.Stevie Sutherland, one of the resilience co-ordinators, said: ldquoI definitely envisage this increasing as it develops.ldquoSome might use it for a couple of days, some might use it for a couple of months.ldquoMaybe we can give a bit more help, askingthere is anything  they need.ldquoNeighbours are also looking after one another and they seem to be managing themselves.ldquoI think most people receiving meals are over .ldquoAll that happens is they are getting one hot meal per day. They might not be getting anything  but itrsquos just making sure they are getting at least one every day.Children have also been receiving wool in craft packs and are encouraged to make colourful pom poms, and hang them from their gates or a nearby lamppost.Stevie said: ldquoThe pom poms will start gathering pace now. Wersquove also put some posts up about it on social media. ldquoHopefully we are going to be inundated with them.ldquoWe want both villages to be decorated with as much colour as possible, in support of frontline workers.Volunteers at the resilience group are continuing to help with prescription and shopping collections.Stevie added: ldquoItrsquos just about getting that help out there.Contact detailsMore information is available on the resilience grouprsquos Facebook and Twitter pages, at facebook groups   and twitter MacmerryTeamMusselburghMusselburghAN AVERAGE of  lunch packs have been prepared and distributed weekly, as well as a daily distribution of emergency food packs by the growing army of  volunteers who make up the Resilient Musselburgh team.And about  free soup and sandwich lunches have been distributed to Whitecraig residents each week, Monday to Friday, by Graham Blaikie, who runs Mercat Grill, helped by Mrs Bennett.The team is also now providing freshly cooked meals.Community Councillor Margaret Stewart explained: ldquoHickory Foods, based at Eskmills, have offered us their kitchen facilities and staff for free to prepare freshly cooked meals which are delivered into the community.ldquoThe staff at the base identy, from referral forms, those who they feel would be most in need and make contact to offer this food support.ldquoWe are trialling this on a two-week basis, where a three-course freshly prepared meal is delivered to those identied for seven days a week.ldquoThis week  meals will have been delivered. This support is specically targeted at vulnerable members of the community, where it is felt that they would benefit from a nutritious meal. All meals are packaged and labelled with instructions for heating.ldquoThis will be reviewed after the first two weeks. However, we have been seeking feedback and, so far, it has been exceptional, with many comments of appreciation and thanks.She added: ldquoWe are still looking to build on our pool of volunteers to ensure sustainability, so anyone who would be interested in supporting us can register via eastlothian.gov.uk info  musselburgh_area_partner ship  resilient_musselburgh.As well as the pound, awarded to the Musselburgh Area Partnership to support the whole community response, Resilient Musselburgh has received a number of funding donations from community groups and organisations.Volunteers have been delivering information leaflets to households in targeted areas and Councillor Andy Forrest arranged for Musselburgh Post Office to deliver leaflets to all other locations.Contact detailsThe Resilient Musselburgh dedicated support number is  .PrestonpansPrestonpansDEMAND for assistance from the Prestonpans resilience team increased last week, reflecting both the pressure families are under going into week five of the lockdown, and a wider awareness of the support available to local people.Allan Sneddon, who is leading the Prestonpans resilience effort, said: ldquoOur volunteers have started providing a dog walking service for several people who are shielding, and this is being co-ordinated on our team leadersrsquo WhatsApp group. This seems to be working very well.ldquoThe three local Scotmid stores in Prestonpans are offering a free home delivery service and, with the help of our resilience volunteersrsquo leaflets advertising the service, have been delivering throughout the town. We are also helping to deliver shopping orders.The Pantry, operating from the Pennypit, also saw demand for meals increase in week four, with  meals delivered to households throughout the town.The Pantry is receiving lots of practical support in the form of food donations from local stores in the area, and financial donations have been given by the Prestonpans and Cockenzie  Port Seton Community Councils, PSG Area Partnership, Prestonpans British Legion, Prestonpans Labour Club and Longniddry Villa FC.Prestonpans Community Council have also set aside funds to help households who are struggling to make ends meet and the Corra Foundation, Scottish Governmentrsquos Food Fund, the Prestonpans British Legion and RBL Scotland Pipe Band have made signicant donations to this fund.Contact detailsIf anyone needs help, they should telephone   or email prestonpansresilience@gmailIF YOUR resilience group would like to purchase copies of the Courier to deliver to residents who are shielding and unable to leave their homes then please email Courier Editor Robbie Scott via rscott@eastlothiancourier for details. Copies can be delivered to a destination of your choice before being distributed by your volunteers.

title: community-resilience-can-turn-help-elphinstone-gifford-haddington-longniddry-tranent
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at five of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Elphinstone. Picture: Google MapsElphinstoneDOG walking, collecting prescriptions, shopping and much more are on offer from generous volunteers in Elphinstone.A spokeswoman for the community highlighted a number of services were on offer to people during the coronavirus pandemic.She said: ldquoThis care has included help with dog walking, collecting prescriptions, shopping, daily delivery of meals and food, a friendly chat over the phone or at a distance from the garden gate.ldquoA number of community partners have rallied to ensure that everyone is cared for during this Covid- pandemic.ldquoThis has only been possible with the operational support of East Lothian Roots and Fruits, Elphinstone Community Association, Elphinstone Primary School, East Lothian Council, Councillor Colin McGinn, Pennypit Community Trust, East Lothian Foodbank, Home-Start East Lothian, Walk With Scott Foundation, Heavy Sound, Social Bite, Tesco, Fair Share, Hibernian Community Foundation and generous donations from McInroy  Wood [Haddington].ldquoThis important work has greatly strengthened relationships and working practices that will continue to grow and develop long after we overcome this devastating pandemic.ldquoCollectively, this network has shown incredible reach, capacity, experience and skills as they endeavour to meet the needs of everyone in need of support.Contact detailsAny residents of Elphinstone who would like to request support can contact the team through email ndash colinmcginn@hotmail ndash or  .Gford. Picture: Google MapsGfordHEARING aid batteries have become the latest item keeping volunteers in Gfordrsquos community resilience team busy with calls for help renewing them.The resilience team has access to replacement batteries through the East Lothian Council community hubs soanyone in need should get in touch.Meanwhile, the team have also spoken about the ldquoprivilege they feel getting to know the stories of so many of their local residents.The grouprsquos spokesperson said: ldquoWe have been getting to know so many of our residents through talking with them and hearing about their lives we have one man who cooked for royalty and so many others with extraordinary tales to share.ldquoIt is a real privilege to get to know them.Contact detailsAnyone needing help can contact: Jo Allen, GCC chair, on   or ChairGfordCC@gmail Adam White, GCC vice chair, on   or adamjswhite@outlook Wendy Ferguson, GCC treasurer, on   or wendyferguson.wf@gmail Aniko Schuetz Bradwell, minister, on   or aschuetzbradwell@churchofscotland.org.ukHaddingtonHaddingtonAN INCREASING number of people are getting in touch with community resilience volunteers in Haddington.The townrsquos community council has been at the heart of setting up a squad of volunteers to help people during the coronavirus pandemic.Chris McEwan, vice-chairman of the community council, stressed they would do whatever they could to help those who needed assistance.He said: ldquoWe have managed in the past few weeks to get our contact details out there a lot better.ldquoPeople are phoning and contacting us, and our volunteers are basically now really getting themselves into a nice routine.ldquoThey have got quite a few people that they are looking after week on week.Services being offered through the resilience volunteers are also increasing.Collections of shopping and prescriptions have been available for a number of weeks.Now, a dog walking service and getting tradesmen out to solve issues in the home have also been introduced.Mr McEwan took the time to once again praise the efforts of the volunteers.He said: ldquoI must say, the town has really, really done well and I have to thank all my volunteers and the people I donrsquot know about who are helping as well.ldquoWe have had people who have had maintenance issues and we have managed to get some tradesmen out to them.ldquoTradesmen are offering to help, some doing it for revenue but a couple doing it for nothing people are helping for nothing.Mr McEwan also highlighted that there was a wide range of information on the grouprsquos website, with sections set up to alert people to community help and coronavirus.On top of that, there is a section for food deliveries, ranging from butchers and bakers to prepared meals and takeaways which are open in the town.The community council plans to keep the list as up to date as possible for people.Contact detailsAnyone looking to find out more can visit www.haddingtoncc.org.uk while anyone looking for assistance can e-mail resilienthcc@haddingtoncc.org.uk or call  .Longniddry. Picture: Google MapsLongniddryONE resident in Longniddry has started offering a free dog walking service for those unable to take their four-legged friend on its daily stroll.Those interested should contact Danni Anderson on Facebook.Meanwhile, the villagersquos resilience effort is still helping those in need and answering queries from residents.It is being led by the local church and supported by Longniddry Community Council.Sheila Jamieson told the Courier that people in the village have been helping family and neighbours on their own accord, so enquiries to her are still fairly low.However, she has still received some enquiries, such as people asking how they can get hearing aid batteries, food parcels and online food deliveries.She currently has  volunteers ready to help her deliver the resilience effort should the need arise.Sheila said: ldquoAs long as people are getting the help they need ndash we are still here and doing what we can.ldquoIrsquom overwhelmed and so grateful for the volunteers and the nice community.ldquoAll of the people in the community are coming together. We are coping at the moment and getting calls from the council with other people who might also need help.As with other resilience groups, it is helping with delivering prescriptions ndash but the local pharmacy offers a delivery service to those over the age of .Contact detailsThose who need any help or assistance can call Sheila Jamieson on  .Tranent. Picture: Google MapsTranentVOLUNTEERS covering Tranent and Elphinstone delivered leaflets to every house in the area, with help from Ross High Rugby Club, reminding people of the help they can receive from their local resilience group.The number of people signed up to volunteer in the area has now risen to , as the number of calls the group receives also continues to rise.The resilience effort in Tranent and Elphinstone is being led by the local community council and overseen by member Mike Falconer.People are continuing to help out with requests such as collecting shopping, picking up prescriptions, and walking dogs.The resilience group is also helping Fundamental Foods and the Pennypit Trust with food deliveries, as well as assisting with its school hub effort.Contact detailsUpdates are also posted on the resilience Facebook page, lsquoTranent Emergency Response ndash Coronavirusrsquo.Updates, information and advice are also shared on Radio Saltire as part of its community information feature.Anyone needing assistance can call   or email tranentemergencyresponse@gmailIF YOUR resilience group would like to purchase copies of the Courier to deliver to residents who are shielding and unable to leave their homes then please email Courier Editor Robbie Scott via rscott@eastlothiancourier for details.
