title: strategy announced lead wales lockdown
story: The framework will help to determine when the strict stay-at-home restrictions can begin to be relaxed in Wales and will help to find a way for people in Wales to live and work alongside coronavirus.A Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing is being developed through the office of the Chief Medical Officer, Dr Frank Atherton. This will highlight the importance of community testing and support the containment of emerging coronavirus infections as and when restrictions are eased.Launching the framework, the First Minister said: ldquoOur approach to date has been one of lockdown. We have taken unprecedented steps to protect everyone, but particularly those most at risk from serious illness.ldquoThis has helped the NHS prepare and cope with coronavirus and, even though we have sadly seen more than  people die, it has helped to save many more lives. But this strategy comes with its own costs to peoplersquos wider health and wellbeing and long-term costs to our economy.ldquoWe are keeping these regulations under constant review. We know coronavirus will be with us for a long time yet but we want to see whether there are things we can do while we continue to tackle the virus and while the search for better treatments and a vaccine continue.The framework ndash and the seven questions ndash will help determine when the time is right to relax some of the stay-at home regulations.The seven questions are:bull Would easing a restriction have a negative effect on containing the virus bull Does a particular measure pose a low risk of further infection bull How can it be monitored and enforced bull Can it be reversed quicklyit creates unintended consequences bull Does it have a positive economic benefit bull Does it have a positive impact on peoplersquos wellbeing bull Does it have a positive impact on equality The Chief Medical Officer for Walesrsquo office has developed the Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing.It will have four main strands ndash improved surveillance of cases of coronavirus effective identication of cases and contact tracing learning from international experience and engaging with the public.Dr Atherton said: ldquoAction to ease the lockdown restrictions will need to be supported by a comprehensive public health response, which will need to developed quickly and at scale.ldquoAcross the UK, we have worked and put in place unprecedented measures to contain and delay the spread of coronavirus. We have also worked to reduce the overall impact of the virus by strengthening essential services, including healthcare.ldquoWe are now working towards a new recovery phase to lead us out of the pandemic but only when the conditions are right.The First Minister added: ldquoCoronavirus is not going to disappear ndash it is likely it will be with us for a long time. We will need to have some sort of restrictions in place for some time yet to continue to control the spread of the virus and reduce community transmission. This framework will help us determine what is right for Wales.ldquoThere is a long road ahead of us towards recovery to pre-pandemic levels, butwe continue to work together, I hope we will be able to make changes to the restrictions and see a gradualto something resembling normal le.The Welsh Government has worked closely with the rest of the UK throughout the pandemic and has shared the development of the framework with the Scottish, Northern Irish and the UK governments. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... story: The framework will help to determine when the strict stay-at-home restrictions can begin to be relaxed in Wales and will help to find a way for people in Wales to live and work alongside coronavirus.A Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing is being developed through the office of the Chief Medical Officer, Dr Frank Atherton. This will highlight the importance of community testing and support the containment of emerging coronavirus infections as and when restrictions are eased.Launching the framework, the First Minister said: ldquoOur approach to date has been one of lockdown. We have taken unprecedented steps to protect everyone, but particularly those most at risk from serious illness.ldquoThis has helped the NHS prepare and cope with coronavirus and, even though we have sadly seen more than  people die, it has helped to save many more lives. But this strategy comes with its own costs to peoplersquos wider health and wellbeing and long-term costs to our economy.ldquoWe are keeping these regulations under constant review. We know coronavirus will be with us for a long time yet but we want to see whether there are things we can do while we continue to tackle the virus and while the search for better treatments and a vaccine continue.The framework ndash and the seven questions ndash will help determine when the time is right to relax some of the stay-at home regulations.The seven questions are:bull Would easing a restriction have a negative effect on containing the virus bull Does a particular measure pose a low risk of further infection bull How can it be monitored and enforced bull Can it be reversed quicklyit creates unintended consequences bull Does it have a positive economic benefit bull Does it have a positive impact on peoplersquos wellbeing bull Does it have a positive impact on equality The Chief Medical Officer for Walesrsquo office has developed the Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing.It will have four main strands ndash improved surveillance of cases of coronavirus effective identication of cases and contact tracing learning from international experience and engaging with the public.Dr Atherton said: ldquoAction to ease the lockdown restrictions will need to be supported by a comprehensive public health response, which will need to developed quickly and at scale.ldquoAcross the UK, we have worked and put in place unprecedented measures to contain and delay the spread of coronavirus. We have also worked to reduce the overall impact of the virus by strengthening essential services, including healthcare.ldquoWe are now working towards a new recovery phase to lead us out of the pandemic but only when the conditions are right.The First Minister added: ldquoCoronavirus is not going to disappear ndash it is likely it will be with us for a long time. We will need to have some sort of restrictions in place for some time yet to continue to control the spread of the virus and reduce community transmission. This framework will help us determine what is right for Wales.ldquoThere is a long road ahead of us towards recovery to pre-pandemic levels, butwe continue to work together, I hope we will be able to make changes to the restrictions and see a gradualto something resembling normal le.The Welsh Government has worked closely with the rest of the UK throughout the pandemic and has shared the development of the framework with the Scottish, Northern Irish and the UK governments. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: charity sends letters offering support vulnerable residents
story: Dinas Powys Voluntary Concern is working in partnership with Dinas Powys Medical Centre to send a letter from the charity to around  residents in the Dinas Powys and District who have been identied as having underlying health problems.They have been advised to stay at home for a duration of  weeks during which time they should shield themselves from physical contact with others.The letter gives information about the help and support that DPVC can offer and how to contact the DPVC Coordinators, Wendy and Judith for assistance with shopping, collecting and delivering prescriptions and telephone calls at regular intervals to ensure that they are safe andany help is needed.Cllr John Fanshaw said the charity was very busy throughout the community.He said: ldquoWe are still keen to offer further assistance. who remain dear to them.ldquoTo ensure that this can continue, we ask all visitors to take good care of themselves and others by observing current health guidance, including social distancing.ldquoWe closed.ldquoFor health and safety reasons, it will be necessary for us to close the grounds during a funeral.ldquoIn current circumstances grounds maintenance has been scaled back and normal maintenance levels will resume when it is safe to do so.ldquoWe hope that reopening the cemetery brings comfort and thank you for supporting us in keeping yourself and others safe.The change comes after the Welsh Government introduced minor adjustments to the lockdown measures.The new rules allow people to exercise more than once a day near their home and enabled local authorities to begin the process of planning how to safely reopen libraries and municipal recycling centres.Garden centres are also allowed to reopen.Last week there were several incidents at the Merthyr Dyfan Cemetery in Barry which reopened on May .Barry Town Council received reports that visitors had not observed social distancing.On one occasion, a member of the public spat at a security guard whilst another title: downton abbey rail line   fundraising bid aid lockdown recovery
story: The Bluebell Railway has hosted big names including Daniel Radclfe and Dame Maggie Smith during its -year history.But now, with the coronavirus pandemic slashing income for attractions across the UK, the heritage rail line in East Sussex knows that the recovery period will be ldquocritical. vw,vw,px, px"Downton Abbey cast members during filming Fundraising organiser Trevor Swainson said: ldquoSurviving the lockdown was the first priority but the recovery period once the Bluebell Railway reopens is also critical.ldquoWe will have little revenue but most of the payroll and overheads will be incurred.ldquoTherefore, it has been decided to launch a major fundraising campaign to support the recovery period rather than funding the survival period.The Bluebell Railway launched an initial appeal in March after it closed because of the Covid- pandemic.With over  donors, our Emergency Appeal has now raised over pound,.Now, we are expanding this appeal to raise the total to at least pound,. Funds raised will support the immediate costs of re-opening the Railway.Full details are available here: https:t.co iILrzBCtp pic rwTnjWbXHmdash Bluebell RailwayMay , It asked supporters to donate and the appeal has raised more than pound, so far.It is now extending the appeal with targeted requests and is hoping to raise at least pound, more.Alongside the appeal, the railway has created a specialist website to allow people to scout for filming locations.The railway has been dubbed ldquoThe Line to the Stars because of its involvement in so many productions. vw,vw,px, px"Daniel Radclfe during filming for The Woman In Black which involved the railway Mike Hopps, a member of the railwayrsquos filming team, said: ldquoWe pride ourselves on being able to offer the very best experience for film production companies with a dedicated department which specialises in supporting filming activities.ldquoOur stations are lsquowalk-on setsrsquo and for more than  years have been the backdrop for hundreds of feature films, TV dramas, fashion shoots and music videos.ndash The fundraising appeal can be accessed at https:uk.virginmoneygiving fund support-bluebellGet involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: northern ireland unveils five point plan exiting coronavirus lockdown
story: A five-point plan with no firm dates has been published for exiting coronavirus restrictions.Those unable to work from home will be encouraged toto work on a phased basis in another early shtthe reproductive rate at which the virus is spread continues to decline below one.Large outdoor-based retailers such as garden centres will also be permitted to reopen in the first step as le edges its way back towards normality.Executive publishes Coronavirus recovery strategy ##https:t.co egDPHjECmdash NI ExecutiveMay , The decision on when to make changes will be guided primarily by the medical and scientic evidence and the NHSrsquos capacity to cope.There is flexibility for dferent parts of the economy such asto schooling and increased use of public transport to move at dferent paces.Drive-through church services will be available and churches will open for private prayer at an early stage.Outdoor spaces and public sport amenities will also be included in the first step of reopening.Large indoor gatherings, nightclubs, concerts, close physical contact sports, restaurants, cafes, pubs and early years education will be included in the final, step five, relaxation.Stormontrsquos next regular three-weekly review of the restrictions is due at the end of May but will be guided by the medical evidence at the time.According to the blueprint, the second step will see groups of  being able to meet outdoors, team sports training allowed on a non-contact basis in small groups, the reopening of some libraries and open-air museums, as well as indoor activities involving limited contact of less than  minutes and with two to four people.The third step will see groups of up to  being able to gather outside, the reopening of more libraries, as well as museums and galleries, concert and theatre rehearsals resuming and larger indoor gatherings.The fourth step will see socially distanced church services, the resumption of competitive sport behind closed doors or with a limited number of spectators, leisure centres reopening and outdoor concerts resuming on a restricted basis.Stormont First Minister Arlene Foster told the Northern Ireland Assembly: ldquoOur road map wonrsquot answer every query ndash it provides an indication, which people can use in looking ahead and anticipating how the next weeks and months might evolve.The Stormont Executive said that, as of May , , iniduals in the region had been tested for Covid-, with , laboratory-confirmed cases and  reported deaths, adding that although overall case numbers are continuing to rise, it is at a slower rate than before.It also notes a ldquogradual decline in both hospital admissions and intensive care unit occupancy, reflecting a reduction in transmission of the virus and progression of the epidemic.The First Minister added: ldquoOur restrictions have worked and they have and are saving lives.ldquoWe are asking a lot of our people, and we appreciate that the restrictions have health and well being consequences too.ldquoWe want everyone to be able to go out, visit relatives, socialise and enjoy everything this place has to offer. We need to get people back to work where safe to do so. We will get there. It will take time, but we will get there.Northern Irelandrsquos R measure of virus transmission is at approximately level . and medics have said they want to drive it down further.The regulations will continue to be reviewed within every three-week period. There may be reviews where no change is warranted and others when more change is possible.Each process of review should not be read as being linked to the next step of the relaxations, Stormontrsquos road map said.Deputy First Minister Michelle OrsquoNeill told the Assembly: ldquoWe are appealing to the public to please be patient.ldquoThe restrictions remain in place at this time, because it is necessary and because it is thankfully working.ldquoOur biggest threat in the fight against Covid- is complacency.ldquoUntil a vaccine is found it means co-existing with the virus and therefore a radical change to how we live our daily lives for some time.ldquoLe as we know it has changed, we will have to continue to adjust..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Northern Ireland unveils five-point plan for exiting coronavirus lockdown article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: china suspends penalties us goods trade truce

January to cancel additional tarf hikes and Beijing committed to buy more American farm exports.US officials said China agreed to address complaints about its technology policies. vw,vw,px, px"US farm goods and other exports.China resumed purchases of American soybeans but has yet to confirm the size of its commitment.Mr Trumprsquos threat rekindled fears in financial markets of more US-Chinese conflict and potential disruption of global trade at a time when economies are reeling from the impact of the coronavirus pandemic.The two sides have raised duties on tens of billions of dollars of each otherrsquos imports in a dispute over Chinarsquos technology ambitions and trade surplus.Slumping economic activity due to coronavirus has prompted suggestions China might be unable to carry out commitments to boost imports.Last week, US and Chinese trade negotiators promised to create ldquofavourable conditions for carrying out the truce, Chinarsquos government announced.The two sides gave no timeline for more talks.Tuesdayrsquos announcement was the third Chinese tarf cut since the January agreement.Beijing announced on February  it would reduce duties on  billion dollarsof story: Warning as NI lakes treated for algae poisonous to dogsWoman left shaken and injured after altercation with male in NI town - PSNI appeal for witnessesNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsCoronavirus: Shoppers told to think of others more needy than themselves when ordering grocery deliveriesConsumers are being urged to think of others before themselves when shopping online, amid an “unprecedented” swell in demand for food deliveries.By Adam KulaMonday, th May , : pm""Image showing a -minute wait today before shoppers can even see the delivery scheduleAodhan Connolly, spokesman for the Northern Irish wing of the British Retail Consortium, said that given the pressures on the system, deliveries should be left for only the elderly, infirm and at-risk.He also indicated that supermarkets are on something of a hiring spree right now, because of the extra manpower needed to pick customers’ baskets of groceries and deliver them.He was speaking just as the News Letter carried out a snap survey of how dferent supermarkets are catering to this spike in demand.This reporter, based in east Antrim, attempted to order groceries from five big chains which are known to deliver .Iceland did not allow this reporter to look at available delivery slots online for  minutes, because there was a queue for doing so.When it did display the delivery times, there was just one slot availablebetween noon today and Sunday, May .Sainsbury’s showed no availability for at least an entire week, ending Monday, May .Asda was unavailable until Sunday May  when some evening slots were free – but only for orders which had no alcohol.Tesco had no slots available until at least Sunday, March  .SuperValu’s nearest storecould not be reached by phone, but it is understood said they deliver only to the elderly and vulnerable, and then only in “the local community”.Mr Connollytold the News Letter: “We’ve had a growth in deliveries that’s unprecedented. We’ve seen some retailers doing delivery numbers they thought they’d be doing in eight years’ time.“But there’s a big, big thing here - there are people out there, disabled, elderly, and we’re asking the public to think before they click. Quite simply, delivery slots should be for the most vulnerable in society.”Instead the public should either get their own groceriesor get click-and-collects.The whole surge means that “here in Northern Ireland our retailers are hiring proportionately... some are permanent contracts, some are temporary”.He said they were “hiring for attitude, and training for skill” - meaning people with few qualications can still find roles in the supermarkets.He also said that “one of the laziest  narratives out there is that retailers are making a killing”. Rather, their margins have been squeezed by people buying cheaper ‘own brand’ goods instead of treating themselves.Lastly, he voiced “pride” in how day-to-day staff are handling themselves in the crisis, adding there is a “zero tolerance” approach to people shouting and becoming confrontationalasked to socially distance themselves.A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website.
